title: On Podcasts and Radio, Misleading Covid-19 Talk Goes Unchecked
content: False statements about vaccines have spread on the “Wild West” of media, even as some hosts die of virus complications.

more_info.byline: By Tiffany Hsu and Marc Tracy

title: As Holidays Near, Bosses Try to Coax Vietnam’s Workers Back to Factories
content: Vietnam, one of the world’s largest suppliers of apparel and footwear, is experiencing a labor shortage. Many employees are reluctant to return after a harsh summer lockdown.

more_info.byline: By Sui-Lee Wee and Vo Kieu Bao Uyen

title: Peace Corps Volunteers Fall Through the Cracks of a Student Loan Fix
content: A deserving group of dedicated people has been left out of the government’s latest patch for the Public Service Loan Forgiveness program.

title: Kaiser Permanente Reaches Tentative Deal With Unions, Averting Strike
content: More than 30,000 West Coast workers at the health care provider had planned to go on strike on Monday.

title: Deere Reaches Third Tentative Deal With Union in Attempt to End Strike
content: About 10,000 workers primarily in Iowa and Illinois have been out since Oct. 14. They rejected two previous contract proposals negotiated by the United Automobile Workers.

title: What Bosses Really Think About the Future of the Office
content: C.E.O.s are eager for employees to return — and afraid of alienating those who have grown accustomed to working from home.

title: Starting a Business With Your 401(k)? Be Careful.
content: As an aspiring entrepreneur, you may have a good idea, but tread lightly before using retirement savings as capital.

title: Tips for Holding Down Your Winter Heating Bills
content: Start with insulating the attic and turning down the thermostat at night. And there’s always your father’s advice: Wear a sweater.

title: Business Schools Respond to a Flood of Interest in E.S.G.
content: As the number of jobs focused on environmental, social and governance issues grows, M.B.A. programs are updating their courses to meet demand from students and recruiters.

title: Crunch at Ports May Mean Crisis for Family Farms
content: Backlogs and cancellations are hitting American growers as costs rise, profits slump and overseas customers shop elsewhere.

title: The Crypto Capital of the World
content: It has to be somewhere. Why not Ukraine?

more_info.byline: By David Segal and Ivan Nechepurenko

title: AstraZeneca says it will start profiting from its vaccine.
content: Countries have been paying about $3 to $4 per shot for AstraZeneca’s vaccine under the company’s not-for-profit pricing model.

more_info.byline: By Rebecca Robbins and Todd Gregory

title: Judge Ends Conservatorship Overseeing Britney Spears’s Life and Finances
content: The pop star had called the arrangement, which governed her life for nearly 14 years, exploitative. A judge ruled it was “no longer required.”

more_info.byline: By Joe Coscarelli and Julia Jacobs

title: Johnson & Johnson, Iconic Company Under Pressure, Plans to Split in Two
content: The 135-year-old company announced plans to divide itself into a consumer products business and a medical company.

more_info.byline: By Rebecca Robbins and Michael J. de la Merced

title: Helene Fortunoff, Who Built a Family Jewelry Empire, Dies at 88
content: A powerhouse female executive in a male-dominated industry, she hired a team of mostly women buyers who traveled the world to find unusual gems.

title: Inflation is driving a sharp downturn in U.S. consumer views about the economy.
content: A University of Michigan survey registered the lowest reading in a decade, reflecting unease about the present and the future.

title: Will Real Estate Ever Be Normal Again?
content: In Austin and cities around the country, prices are skyrocketing, forcing regular people to act like speculators. When will it end?

title: Fashionably Late to the Climate Crisis
content: How do you fix the fashion industry? This sustainability expert has a few ideas.

more_info.byline: By Julia Rothman and Shaina Feinberg

title: ‘Be Nice to Tourists’: New York’s Arts Scene Needs International Visitors
content: The United States now allows vaccinated international travelers into the country. It’s welcome news for arts institutions that lost revenue and cut jobs during the pandemic.

title: The number of U.S. workers quitting their jobs in September was the highest on record.
content: Nearly a million workers quit in the leisure and hospitality industry alone, reflecting the competition for workers after pandemic-induced shutdowns.

title: Biden Chooses Robert Califf to Lead F.D.A., Despite Drug Industry Ties
content: Dr. Robert M. Califf, an academic and clinical trial researcher who ran the agency in 2016, has also consulted for pharmaceutical companies.

more_info.byline: By Sheryl Gay Stolberg and Sheila Kaplan

title: These Investors May Believe Biden on Inflation
content: Has the president found a corner of the market that has faith in his pledge to contain rising prices?

more_info.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni

title: Now TV Wants Nielsen to Measure Up
content: After years of complaints, NBCUniversal and its peers are looking for other ways to count viewers, with or without the ratings giant.

title: 275 Minutes on Hold: Why Airline Customer Service Still Can’t Keep Up
content: It’s been a familiar and infuriating story during the pandemic: Hours waiting for an agent only to have the call dropped. The ordeal of rescheduling canceled flights. Delayed refunds. What gives?

title: The White House Says Its Plans Will Slow Inflation. The Big Question Is: When?
content: The Biden administration has argued that its infrastructure and broader economic package will slow rapid price increases. But that will take time.

more_info.byline: By Jeanna Smialek and Jim Tankersley

title: What We Learned From Tim Cook, Antony Blinken, Mary Barra and More
content: China, inflation, electric vehicles, deplatforming and other hot topics dominated the DealBook Online Summit this year.

more_info.byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni

title: Britain’s economic recovery has slowed as supply disruptions persist.
content: The economy grew 1.3 percent in the third quarter, down from 5.5 percent growth in the previous three months.

title: Alibaba reports slower sales growth for its Singles Day shopping event.
content: Sales grew 8.5 percent from last year, but had grown 26 percent in 2020 from the year before.

title: A New Mercedes SL Stresses Horsepower and Verve
content: Across seven decades, the roadster has radiated a sporty elegance, and a new generation adds a dash of modern driving technology.

title: The Core Legal Strategy Against Opioid Companies May Be Faltering
content: Two recent rulings rejected the “public nuisance” argument being used in thousands of cases against the industry, with more trials and settlement talks underway.

title: Stocks Soar in India, Luring Investors at Home and Abroad
content: The second-most populous country is enjoying some of the world’s strongest stock market returns. Pro-growth policies and gnawing questions about China have helped.

more_info.byline: By Matt Phillips and Emily Schmall

title: California Businessman Is Sentenced to 30 Years in $1 Billion Ponzi Scheme
content: Jeff Carpoff, 50, ran a Ponzi scheme with his wife that sold nonexistent solar generators to investors, prosecutors said.

title: Elon Musk sells $5 billion in Tesla shares, partly to cover taxes on stock options.
content: The sales so far were considerably short of the $20 billion worth he promised over the weekend that he would sell.
